nodes.title: Prompt Informations
widgets_values:
When writing prompts, focus on detailed, chronological descriptions of actions and scenes. Include specific movements, appearances, camera angles, and environmental details - all in a single flowing paragraph. Start directly with the action, and keep descriptions literal and precise. Think like a cinematographer describing a shot list. Keep within 200 words. For best results, build your prompts using this structure:

Start with main action in a single sentence
Add specific details about movements and gestures
Describe character/object appearances precisely
Include background and environment details
Specify camera angles and movements
Describe lighting and colors
Note any changes or sudden events

nodes.title: Video Combine 🎥🅥🅗🅢 Final Video With All Active Sequences.
Florence2 prompt Informations
widgets_values:
The prompt in my workflow works in two ways.
For the first method, you can provide an image to Florence2 using the 'Load Image I2V Injection' node. It will generate a prompt for you, and within the Florence2 nodes, there's a text node where you can also add some custom text.

For the second method, you need to set the 'Use Florence2' node to OFF. In this case, it will use the prompt from the 'Simple Prompt Only' node, where you must write the prompt yourself. It's also possible to copy the prompt generated by Florence, paste it into the 'Simple Prompt Only' node, and modify it as you wish.

nodes.title: LTX Model Option Informations
widgets_values:
Using STG Mode is a bit slower, and it doesn’t always make significant changes to the generation results, but in general, the results tend to be better. For STG mode, the default value is 14, but you can experiment with other values to see the differences for yourself. You can also adjust the perturbed attention, which can significantly impact the generation results, including reducing or increasing movement.

The model sampling option is similar to STG, but it doesn’t affect generation speed. You can try different values here as well and determine what works best for your needs.

For the model sampler, dpm_2 generally produces excellent results. While you can use other samplers, they often require more steps. The dpm_2 sampler can deliver better results with a low step count, but it is approximately twice as slow to process. If you use, for example, the euler sampler, the generation speed will be faster, but you may need to use more steps, potentially increasing the total generation time. Ultimately, the generation time for dpm_2 with low steps versus euler or others with more steps ends up being fairly similar. It’s a personal choice based on your preferences and needs.

My sampler node doesn’t include a scheduler option. This is intentional, as my refiner method works exclusively with one scheduler mode, which is internally set by default. If you need scheduler options, check out my other sampler nodes or use a standard sampler.

By default, the LTX model is set to a frame rate of 25 FPS. For example, if you use 24 FPS instead of 25 in the conditioning, it will completely change the generation results. This is how the LTX model works. If you disable prompt conditioning, the generation will default to 25 FPS.

Personally, I often use 24 FPS, and it seems to give me good results most of the time. You can experiment by turning it on and off to see the difference for yourself.

For generating subsequent sequences, I use a lower CFG value because, in my tests, it seemed that using a higher CFG led to excessive accumulation as more sequences were added. The results appeared better when reducing the CFG for the later sequences.

However, my method is experimental, so various settings in the model may cause different reactions. The best approach is to experiment and find what works best for your needs.

nodes.title: FaceSwap Informations
widgets_values:
Method 1:

How to use FaceSwap with LTX?
There are two ways to do it.

The first method requires activating the I2V mode. You need to load an image in the Load Image I2V Injection in the orange nodes. Then, load a face image in the Load Face Image in the purple nodes. Next, load the image you want to modify in the Load or Copy FaceSwap Image, also in the purple nodes.

Make sure to activate Use FaceSwap, and then you can start generating the video. Be sure to use a prompt that matches your image. It might seem complicated at first, but once you understand the process, you'll find it simple.


Method 2:

Method 2 is the simplest.
Activate T2V mode in the orange nodes.

First, generate the video. Once the video is generated, go to FaceSwap in the purple nodes. Activate FaceSwap, load a face, and FaceSwap will generate an image of the first frame of the video with your face. Load this image into "Load Image - I2V Injection Mode & FaceSwap Image" node.

Then activate I2V mode to regenerate the video again with the new face.

It might still seem complicated, but once you understand the process, it’s very simple.

nodes.title: General Workflow Informations
widgets_values:
Dave Gravel LTX workflow for 2025 with my custom sampler node.

To use my workflow without it looking like a spaghetti mess of lines, go to the ComfyUI options and select Lite Graph. In this menu, find the 'Link Render Mode' option and set it to 'Straight.' This should make the workflow much clearer. Alternatively, you can always use the option to hide all the lines.

My workflow and custom sampler node come with an example video, but I’ll still try to briefly explain what the workflow includes and what it’s used for.

This workflow is designed for two modes only: T2V (Text-to-Video) and I2V (Image-to-Video). It can also generate a prompt from an image using Florence2. Additionally, it’s possible to swap faces in videos using FaceSwap or simply add an image with a modified face from another workflow. For example, you can save the last frame of the first video, use it as a latent image (e.g., with Flux), apply a LoRA or other adjustments, and reuse this modified image for video generation.

With my workflow, it’s also possible to extend videos up to 30 seconds or more. If you generate all the workflow sequences with 121 frames each, this will result in a 30-second video. If you have enough memory to generate more than 121 frames per sequence, you can create videos longer than 30 seconds. It’s also possible to extend beyond that by adding more sampler nodes, but typically after 20–30 seconds, the results start to look more like animations or shaders, with a loss of realism over time.

You may be able to reduce this effect by using gradual and different values for each sampler, though I haven’t had the time to test everything. I have noticed that reducing the CFG for subsequent sequences can slightly mitigate the effect.

How the Refiner Mode Works in My Custom Sampler Node
The refiner mode is relatively simple, though a bit complex to explain fully. Generally, the refiner is only used for the first video sequence. It enhances the video and can sometimes correct objects in the scene. In most cases, it tries to reproduce the same scene but with improvements.

In general, the refiner reproduces the scene but enhances it. However, it can happen that the refinement produces a final result completely different from the first generation. It is always better to try generating the video with a refinement count of 0 for the first attempt and then try a count of 1 or 2 if the result does not meet your expectations.

Using the refiner requires more generation time because it involves an additional pass. For example, if you use 10 steps and the refiner count is set to 1, the sampler will make two passes of 10 steps each. Typically, a refiner count of 1 is sufficient, but you can use higher values if needed.

If, for example, you use the refiner with a count of 1, it will refine the video. However, if you change the face and use this image to regenerate the video, you can set the refiner count to 0 because it won't refine an already refined video. This will save you a lot of time during generation.

For example, with the first sequence, if you use a refiner with a count of 1, it means the sampler will make 2 passes based on the number of steps you set. If you want to create sequences one after another, you might need to double the steps for the subsequent sequences to ensure continuity. For instance, if the first sequence is done with 10 steps and a refiner count of 1, in the other samplers, you would likely need to use 20 steps and a refiner count of 0.

For subsequent sequences, the refiner count is usually set to 0. You can try higher values, but it’s unlikely to make a difference. The refiner steps are generally the same as the normal video steps, though you can experiment with different values—just keep in mind that results may vary. This is still highly experimental, and there are many options to consider, so the best approach is to experiment.

If one of the sequences does not produce the desired result compared to the previous one, change the seed for that sequence, and it will regenerate only that sequence.

Sequence System for Extending Video Length
The sequence system works in order, so you must activate or deactivate groups sequentially. For example, if you activate sequences 1, 2, and 3 but deactivate 4 and then activate 5, you will encounter an error.

If you use 121 frames, each sequence will last for 5 seconds. You can leave the "Final All Sequences" group activated—it won’t cause any issues. For other sequences, only activate the ones you need for the desired duration, and make sure to activate them in order (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, etc.).

FaceSwap Functionality
The FaceSwap feature works only in I2V mode, even if it’s activated. In T2V mode, you can still leave it activated to see the face change result, but it won’t apply to the generation. To apply FaceSwap, you need to load the modified image into the 'Load Image - I2V Injection Mode & FaceSwap Image' node.

If you want to use I2V mode without applying FaceSwap, set the 'Use FaceSwap' option to OFF.

The best way to use FaceSwap is to generate the first video sequence in T2V mode, apply the modified face to the first frame of the video, load the modified image into the 'Load Image - I2V Injection Mode & FaceSwap Image' node, then switch from T2V to I2V mode. This way, the generation uses an image almost entirely produced by the model itself, with only the face modified. This method seems to yield better results.

Final Notes
I believe I’ve covered the main features of my workflow and custom sampler node. For further details, you can refer to my example video or contact me if you have questions or issues. Just keep in mind that everything is experimental.

I created these 3 sampler nodes for the LTX model, but they can be used with almost any model, including image models. If you understand how my nodes work, you'll know how to use them, as there are too many possible options to explain them all in writing. In fact, there are likely even more possibilities that I haven't had the chance to experiment with myself.

I don't know exactly why, but here, when I use the GGUF Q8 model, the generation seems to be a bit faster than with the Q4 model.

The 0.9.1 model seems slightly better at times in the final output and a bit faster, but the 0.9.0 model appears to be more stable for generating multiple sequences. With the 0.9.1 model, it's more often necessary to change the seeds of sequences to achieve the desired result.

You can find the gguf model here:
https://huggingface.co/calcuis/ltxv-gguf/tree/main

Old version here:
https://huggingface.co/city96/LTX-Video-gguf/tree/main

The clip encoder gguf here:
https://huggingface.co/city96/t5-v1_1-xxl-encoder-gguf/tree/main

My workflow involves working with both LTX versions, 0.9.0 and 0.9.1. Just remember that both versions use different VAEs.

widgets_values: The video is a black and white abstract art piece that appears to be made up of multiple horizontal lines that are arranged in a zigzag pattern. The lines are evenly spaced and run horizontally across the video. In the center of the video, there is a small figure of a zebra that is facing towards the right side of the frame. The zebra's head is slightly tilted downwards, as if it is looking down at the viewer. The figure's body is covered in a thin layer of black lines that create a sense of depth and dimension. The overall effect is a striking contrast between the lines and the figure. The scene is captured in real-life footage.

widgets_values: The video is a black and white abstract art piece that appears to be made up of multiple horizontal lines that are arranged in a zigzag pattern. The lines are evenly spaced and run horizontally across the video. In the center of the video, there is a small figure of a zebra that is facing towards the right side of the frame. The zebra's head is slightly tilted downwards, as if it is looking down at the viewer. The figure's body is covered in a thin layer of black lines that create a sense of depth and dimension. The overall effect is a striking contrast between the lines and the figure. The scene is captured in real-life footage.

Due to not having much time these past few months to focus and work on 3D programming, I’m going to relax a bit and chill while trying out my latest workflow for LTX videos and wrap up the year with that. I wish you all a Happy New Year 2025, and I hope for nothing but the best for you—good health and all the best things to come.

Updated workflow:
I have fix some logic node in the faceswap section.
I have add the possibility to have a custom prompt in all sequence.
I have add a quick upscaler section.

nodes.title: Information about the upscaler
widgets_values:
If you are running low in vram use the tiled encoder node, and in my sampler enable the tiled decoder. Because if you bust your memory vram it can cause computer crash or some freeze.
The memory usage here depend a lot on the scale size and the video resolution.

A woman with long brown hair and light skin smiles at another woman...
A woman with long brown hair and light skin smiles at another woman with long blonde hair. The woman with brown hair wears a black jacket and has a small, barely noticeable mole on her right cheek. The camera angle is a close-up, focused on the woman with brown hair's face. The lighting is warm and natural, likely from the setting sun, casting a soft glow on the scene. The scene appears to be real-life footage.


A woman walks away from a white Jeep parked on a city street at night...
A woman walks away from a white Jeep parked on a city street at night, then ascends a staircase and knocks on a door. The woman, wearing a dark jacket and jeans, walks away from the Jeep parked on the left side of the street, her back to the camera; she walks at a steady pace, her arms swinging slightly by her sides; the street is dimly lit, with streetlights casting pools of light on the wet pavement; a man in a dark jacket and jeans walks past the Jeep in the opposite direction; the camera follows the woman from behind as she walks up a set of stairs towards a building with a green door; she reaches the top of the stairs and turns left, continuing to walk towards the building; she reaches the door and knocks on it with her right hand; the camera remains stationary, focused on the doorway; the scene is captured in real-life footage.

A woman with blonde hair styled up, wearing a black dress with sequins and pearl earrings, looks down with a sad expression on her face. The camera remains stationary, focused on the woman's face. The lighting is dim, casting soft shadows on her face. The scene appears to be from a movie or TV show.


The camera pans over a snow-covered mountain range...
The camera pans over a snow-covered mountain range, revealing a vast expanse of snow-capped peaks and valleys.The mountains are covered in a thick layer of snow, with some areas appearing almost white while others have a slightly darker, almost grayish hue. The peaks are jagged and irregular, with some rising sharply into the sky while others are more rounded. The valleys are deep and narrow, with steep slopes that are also covered in snow. The trees in the foreground are mostly bare, with only a few leaves remaining on their branches. The sky is overcast, with thick clouds obscuring the sun. The overall impression is one of peace and tranquility, with the snow-covered mountains standing as a testament to the power and beauty of nature.

He holds the black rotary phone to his right ear with his right hand, his left hand holding a rocks glass with amber liquid. He wears a brown suit jacket over a white shirt, and a gold ring on his left ring finger. His short hair is neatly combed, and he has light skin with visible wrinkles around his eyes. The camera remains stationary, focused on his face and upper body. The room is dark, lit only by a warm light source off-screen to the left, casting shadows on the wall behind him. The scene appears to be from a movie.

The woman, wearing a dark blue shirt, sits opposite the young man, her face turned towards him; she has short blonde hair and light skin. The camera remains stationary, capturing the scene from a medium distance, positioned slightly to the right of the guard. The room is dimly lit, with a single light fixture illuminating the table and the two figures. The walls are made of large, grey concrete blocks, and a metal door is visible in the background. He has short gray hair, light skin, and a serious expression. He places his right hand on the back of a chair as he approaches the couch. He then turns his entire body to the right, facing the window. The camera remains stationary as he stands in front of the window. The scene is captured in real-life footage.

groups.title: DG LTX + Special OrionX3D Sampler - Sequence 1
